title: Hurricane Preparedness: Before, During & After
description: Essential information to help you prepare for, survive during, and recover after a hurricane.

sections.title: Before a Hurricane
sections.content:
## Know Your Risk

- Know if you live in an evacuation area
- Assess your home for vulnerability to storm surge, flooding, and wind
- Research your community's hurricane response plan

## Make a Plan

- Determine where to evacuate if needed
- Create a family communication plan
- Plan for pets and livestock
- Have a backup plan for medical needs or disabilities

## Prepare Your Home

- Clear gutters and storm drains
- Trim trees and shrubs
- Reinforce garage doors
- Secure or bring in outdoor furniture
- Consider installing hurricane shutters or boarding up windows
- Review insurance policies

## Build a Kit

- Water (1 gallon per person per day for at least 3 days)
- Non-perishable food (at least 3-day supply)
- Medications and medical supplies
- First aid kit
- Battery-powered or hand-crank radio
- Flashlights and extra batteries
- Cash and important documents in waterproof container
- Full tank of gas in vehicles

sections.title: During a Hurricane
sections.content:
## If Evacuating

- Leave early to avoid traffic and deteriorating weather
- Follow designated evacuation routes
- Take only essential items
- Lock your home
- Notify friends and family of your route and destination

## If Staying Home (Sheltering in Place)

- Stay indoors and away from windows and glass doors
- Close all interior doors and secure exterior doors
- Keep curtains and blinds closed
- Take refuge in a small interior room, closet, or hallway on the lowest level
- Lie on the floor under a table or other sturdy object if the building experiences severe winds
- Do not be fooled by a lull in the storm – it could be the eye of the hurricane and winds will pick up again

sections.title: After a Hurricane
sections.content:
## Safety First

- Watch for downed power lines and report them immediately
- Stay out of floodwater – it may be contaminated or electrically charged
- Use a generator safely – never use indoors, including in garages or carports
- Beware of dangerous debris, damaged structures, and wildlife displaced by the storm

## Returning Home

- Do not return until authorities say it is safe
- Look for external damage before entering
- If you smell gas, leave immediately and call 9-1-1
- Document damage with photos for insurance claims
- Clean and disinfect everything that got wet
- Throw away food that may have been contaminated

## Recovery Resources

- Register with FEMA for disaster assistance if your area receives a disaster declaration
- Contact your insurance company promptly
- Be wary of contractor fraud – verify credentials before hiring
